defs.name: lock
defs.docs: Locks the spinlock and returns a guard.

/ The returned value may be dereferenced for data access

defs.name: force_unlock
defs.docs: Force unlock the spinlock.

attributes.value: / This is *extremely* unsafe if the lock is not held by the current
/ thread. However, this can be useful in some instances for exposing the
/ lock to FFI that doesn't know how to deal with RAII.
/ If the lock isn't held, this is a no-op.

defs.name: try_lock
defs.docs:
Tries to lock the mutex. If it is already locked, it will return None. Otherwise it returns
 a guard within Some.

defs.name: RwLock
defs.docs: A reader-writer lock

attributes.value: / This type of lock allows a number of readers or at most one writer at any
/ point in time. The write portion of this lock typically allows modification
/ of the underlying data (exclusive access) and the read portion of this lock
/ typically allows for read-only access (shared access).
/ The type parameter `T` represents the data that this lock protects. It is
/ required that `T` satisfies `Send` to be shared across tasks and `Sync` to
/ allow concurrent access through readers. The RAII guards returned from the
/ locking methods implement `Deref` (and `DerefMut` for the `write` methods)
/ to allow access to the contained of the lock.
/ An [`RwLockUpgradeableGuard`](RwLockUpgradeableGuard) can be upgraded to a
/ Writable or upgradeable guards can be downgraded through their respective `downgrade`
/ This implementation is unfair to writers - if the lock always has readers, then no writers will
/ ever get a chance. Using an upgradeable lock guard can *somewhat* alleviate this issue as no
/ new readers are allowed when an upgradeable guard is held, but upgradeable guards can be taken
/ when there are existing readers. However if the lock is that highly contended and writes are
/ crucial then this implementation may be a poor choice.
/ // many reader locks can be held at once
/ } // read locks are dropped at this point
/ // only one write lock may be held, however

attributes.value: / A guard from which the protected data can be read

defs.name: RwLockWriteGuard
defs.docs: A guard to which the protected data can be written

attributes.value: / A guard to which the protected data can be written
/ When the guard falls out of scope it will release the lock.

defs.name: RwLockUpgradeableGuard
defs.docs:
A guard from which the protected data can be read, and can be upgraded
 to a writable guard if needed

attributes.value: / A guard from which the protected data can be read, and can be upgraded
/ to a writable guard if needed
/ No writers or other upgradeable guards can exist while this is in scope. New reader
/ creation is prevented (to alleviate writer starvation) but there may be existing readers
/ When the guard falls out of scope it will release the lock.

defs.name: read
defs.docs:
Locks this rwlock with shared read access, blocking the current thread
 until it can be acquired.

attributes.value: / Locks this rwlock with shared read access, blocking the current thread
/ The calling thread will be blocked until there are no more writers which
/ hold the lock. There may be other readers currently inside the lock when
/ this method returns. This method does not provide any guarantees with
/ respect to the ordering of whether contentious readers or writers will
/ Returns an RAII guard which will release this thread's shared access
/     // The lock is now locked and the data can be read

defs.name: try_read
defs.docs: Attempt to acquire this lock with shared read access.

attributes.value: / Attempt to acquire this lock with shared read access.
/ This function will never block and will return immediately if `read`
/ would otherwise succeed. Returns `Some` of an RAII guard which will
/ release the shared access of this thread when dropped, or `None` if the
/ access could not be granted. This method does not provide any
/ guarantees with respect to the ordering of whether contentious readers
/ or writers will acquire the lock first.
/             // The lock is now locked and the data can be read

defs.name: force_read_decrement
defs.docs: Force decrement the reader count.

attributes.value: / This is *extremely* unsafe if there are outstanding `RwLockReadGuard`s
/ live, or if called more times than `read` has been called, but can be
/ useful in FFI contexts where the caller doesn't know how to deal with
/ RAII. The underlying atomic operation uses `Ordering::Release`.

defs.name: force_write_unlock
defs.docs: Force unlock exclusive write access.

attributes.value: / This is *extremely* unsafe if there are outstanding `RwLockWriteGuard`s
/ live, or if called when there are current readers, but can be useful in
/ FFI contexts where the caller doesn't know how to deal with RAII. The

defs.name: write
defs.docs:
Lock this rwlock with exclusive write access, blocking the current
 thread until it can be acquired.

attributes.value: / Lock this rwlock with exclusive write access, blocking the current
/ thread until it can be acquired.
/ This function will not return while other writers or other readers
/ currently have access to the lock.
/ Returns an RAII guard which will drop the write access of this rwlock
/     // The lock is now locked and the data can be written

defs.name: try_write
defs.docs: Attempt to lock this rwlock with exclusive write access.

/ to `write` would otherwise block. If successful, an RAII guard is
/             // The lock is now locked and the data can be written

defs.name: upgradeable_read
defs.docs:
Obtain a readable lock guard that can later be upgraded to a writable lock guard.
 Upgrades can be done through the [`RwLockUpgradeableGuard::upgrade`](RwLockUpgradeableGuard::upgrade) method.

attributes.value: / Obtain a readable lock guard that can later be upgraded to a writable lock guard.
/ Upgrades can be done through the [`RwLockUpgradeableGuard::upgrade`](RwLockUpgradeableGuard::upgrade) method.

defs.name: upgrade
defs.docs: Upgrades an upgradeable lock guard to a writable lock guard.

defs.name: downgrade
defs.docs: Downgrades the upgradeable lock guard to a readable, shared lock guard. Cannot fail and is guaranteed not to spin.

attributes.value: / Downgrades the upgradeable lock guard to a readable, shared lock guard. Cannot fail and is guaranteed not to spin.
/ let readable = upgradeable.downgrade(); // This is guaranteed not to spin

defs.name: downgrade
defs.docs: Downgrades the writable lock guard to a readable, shared lock guard. Cannot fail and is guaranteed not to spin.

defs.name: Once
defs.docs:
A synchronization primitive which can be used to run a one-time global
 initialization. Unlike its std equivalent, this is generalized so that the
 closure returns a value and it is stored. Once therefore acts something like
 a future, too.

attributes.value: / A synchronization primitive which can be used to run a one-time global

defs.name: INIT

defs.name: call_once
defs.value: pub fn call_once<'a, F>(&'a Self, F) -> &'a T where F: FnOnce() -> T
defs.docs:
Performs an initialization routine once and only once. The given closure
 will be executed if this is the first time `call_once` has been called,
 and otherwise the routine will *not* be invoked.

attributes.value: / Performs an initialization routine once and only once. The given closure
/ will be executed if this is the first time `call_once` has been called,
/ and otherwise the routine will *not* be invoked.
/ This method will block the calling thread if another initialization
/ When this function returns, it is guaranteed that some initialization
/ has run and completed (it may not be the closure specified). The
/ returned pointer will point to the result from the closure that was
